Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2008 05:18AM mattscot wrote: thanks for the info...Does  your oncologist plan on pursuing this with Genomic Health... I would  request maybe a retest (without charge...) What about the breakdown of the test... it is based on the ER, PR, HER2 what was the factor for the high score... ??  You can also contact them and speak directly.  Good for you on the hormonals only --- some Doctors would not have even sent in for the Oncotype given your favorable results...,..
Posts.Title: Oncotype DX Score - shocked at oncologist recommendation kmab15 otter

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2008 05:05PM mattscot wrote: I think some of this speculation on how the Oncotype is scored... is just not helpful.  When you get the report --- you will need to be walked through it-- by your oncologist or someone at Genomic Health I posted on another site that the Oncotype tested me to be Her2- (as opposed to the FISH test) that had me slightly  positive --   With an ultimate score of 16...  You may find that this test may find you be less ER + than the other test results...  So which do you beleive?..  In my case two tumour boards came to the conclusion that i am probably Her2- but should still do chemo and herceptin...     Please let us know...
Posts.Title: Oncotype DX Score - shocked at oncologist recommendation kmab15 otter

I too have recently lost 20 lbs (over the past 2 years sloow-- via exercise...)  I plan on making it a goal to limit the weight gain-- and continue to excercise -- maybe change intensity on days  when if feel tired I have been also looking into nutrition and cancer -- and would like to make those changes... Of course I still dont know if any of this is really feasible since I did not start the chemo yet...
Posts.Title: weight gain during chemo??? rayhope theprettiestmess

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2008 06:08AM mattscot wrote: I wanted to chime in.... (Note I am HER 2 + so Herceptin is thrown into the mix) I recently obtained my first opinion from MSKettering in Basking ridge NJ -- their protocol is AC T  (dose dense every 2 weeks)  plus Herceptin weekly. They recently performed an internal study in which they determined that when Herceptin combined with dose dense chemo reduces the risk of heart problems..   2nd opinion (NJ - local oncologist)-- pretty much the same ...my understanding is is that this is the standard on the east coast  -- this doctor noted in the west coast the trend now is TCH...   He is willing to offer TCH if I feel strongly. The other difference was after 2mos of AC (every 2 weeks 4x) -- He reccomends Taxol +Herceptin weekly (for 2 mos)  -- Which supposedly is very "doable" esp. after the AC-- Re the oncotype test my oncologist is interested in the results -- even though we know I will be doing chemo...  The test is supposedly reccomended for node neg, ER + to determine if chemo is necessary... and there is now a trend in the invasive lobular cancers that maybe hormone therapy is enough,... since I am HER 2 + that is all moot -- chemo indicated--    Anyway I am leaning towards the AC T --
Posts.Title: AC&T vs T/C? EleanorJ Seabee

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2008 12:55AM mattscot wrote: You can add me I had a score of 16 .. 10% reaccurrance with tamoxiflin only the test found me to be Her 2- when the FISH had previously tested me to be Her+  like Seabee I have lobular -- but pleomorphic variety--  which if you read old journal articles had been considered aggressive  -- but I had a low oncotype score (and I have noticed other pleomorphic ilc with similar scores... which I believe have to do with high ER/PR level and Her- status).  So I have had lots of interesting issues... not really a black and white --clear cut. anyway based on the above, my age--( 49) two young kids ...and that both oncologists I went to said chemo was in order -- (TC x4 plus Herceptin) it was a no brainer for me. Looking at the test itself I believe it is highly driven by your ER/PR level and Her+ status that seems to have the biggest factor in the scoring..

Posts.Title: Acne after treatment Scrappygrl Snappygoddess

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2008 07:18AM mattscot wrote: Renrel, You should search the boards on AC versus TC  ... that really helped me to make my decision with my Doctors support. A has cardiac toxicity issues... it is still considered the gold standard. and is right in certain situations  .. but given your lower Oncoscore TC would make sense.  It is a little odd that your first doctor is telling you either no chemo or AC .  The second doctor sounds wonderful and is an excellent match for you.   The age factor does not seem to be factored into the oncotype test.... nor does the size of the tumor and that historically was a huge factor.  Nor does the type ..ILC versus IDC... What is kind of startling is to see cases of small tumors, low grades with HER- having a high score  ... this must  be connected to a lower ER/PR sensitivity.
